questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 12-day history of increasing pain and swelling of his right knee. For the past 3 weeks, he has experienced episodes of pain when urinating. He had a tender swollen left ankle joint that resolved without treatment one week ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis. He is sexually active with 2 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He appears anxious. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 100/80 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral inflammation of the conjunctiva. The right knee is tender, erythematous, and swollen; range of motion is limited by pain. There is tenderness at the left Achilles tendon insertion site. Genital examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.5 g/dL


Leukocyte count
12,300/mm3



Platelet count
310,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
38 mm/h


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
18 mg/dL


 Glucose
89 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Urine



 Protein
negative


 Blood
negative


 WBC
12–16/hpf


 RBC
1–2/hpf


An ELISA test for HIV is negative. Arthrocentesis is performed. Synovial fluid analysis shows a leukocyte count of 26,000/mm3 (70% neutrophils); a Gram stain shows no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection can manifest in two ways: either with a triad of polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, and dermatitis, or as purulent arthritis (without affection of skin and tendons). This patient's presentation is not consistent with either form. He does have arthritis (but only in a single joint) and tenosynovitis, but lacks cutaneous manifestations. His arthrocentesis did show a high neutrophil count, but the leukocyte count is too low and there were no gonococci on the Gram stain (note that the Gram stain is only positive in < 25% of cases). Even though this does not rule out gonococcal infection, disseminated (!) gonococcal infection usually does not cause urethritis and conjunctivitis (only 25% of patients with gonococcal infection present with genitourinary manifestations).

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis would also present with limited range of motion and the typical combination of erythema, warmth, and swelling. In a patient with no risk factors (e.g., IV drug use), however, it is not very likely. This patient also presents with extraarticular symptoms that make a generalized disease more likely. Furthermore, the leukocyte count (26,000/mm3) is far lower than expected (> 50,000/mm3), and the absence of organisms on Gram stain rules out the most common bacterial causes of septic arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the small joints of the hands and fingers and also causes morning stiffness, none of which is present in this patient. In the case of juvenile idiopathic arthritis, fever and different extraarticular manifestations would be expected, such as uveitis, rashes, or nail changes. Furthermore, urethritis is not commonly seen in rheumatoid arthritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis would cause the same local symptoms seen in this patient. Furthermore, the expected arthrocentesis findings in Lyme arthritis are consistent with this case: specifically, > 50% neutrophils, increased WBCs (> 25,000), and no organisms on Gram stain. Nevertheless, the patient is missing all the typical findings of Lyme disease, including history of a tick bite, erythema chronicum migrans, and flu-like symptoms. Even if stage I went unnoticed and the patient were now in stage II of Lyme disease (with migratory arthralgia), it would not explain his tendinopathy, conjunctivitis, or pain on urination.

E) CORRECT:

Asymmetric oligoarthritis with a migratory character (left ankle → right knee), tendinopathy, and conjunctivitis are typical manifestations of reactive arthritis. This patient's pain on urination is most likely a symptom of a preceding urinary tract infection, as reactive arthritis is a postinfectious autoimmune disorder. The disorder most commonly affects sexually active young men, as they have a higher risk of acquiring STDs, e.g., genitourinary infections with Chlamydia. The arthrocentesis findings are also consistent with this diagnosis, as they tend to show increased WBCs and neutrophils but no organisms. Reactive arthritis can also occur in response to infection with other organisms such as Shigella or Campylobacter. Management includes NSAIDs, physiotherapy, and cryotherapy, and, if applicable, treatment of ongoing infection.

See “Differential diagnoses of infection-associated arthritis” table.

F) INCORRECT:

The patient has no history of a chancre or regional lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis). Moreover, he does not have a polymorphic rash, constitutional symptoms (e.g., generalized lymphadenopathy, fever), or condylomata lata (secondary syphilis).
questions.hint: This condition classically manifests with the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man comes to the physician because of a swollen, tender left knee for the past 4 days. During this period, the patient has had pain with urination. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. He is sexually active with two male partners and they use condoms inconsistently. His older sister has systemic lupus erythematosus. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 98 kg (216 lb); BMI is 30 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 140/75 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctivitis bilaterally. The left knee is warm, erythematous, and tender to touch; range of motion is limited. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 62 mm/h. Urinalysis shows WBCs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Reactive arthritis occurs in genetically susceptible individuals in response to infection with Chlamydia, Shigella, or Campylobacter, among other organisms. An HLA-B27 positive genotype is a predisposing factor in over two-thirds of patients with reactive arthritis. Those with reactive arthritis and a positive HLA-B27 genotype should be screened for other diseases associated with the same genotype, such as ankylosing spondylitis and acute anterior uveitis. Given this patient's sexual history, he should also be screened for HIV, which is associated with a higher risk of reactive arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

A hiking trip might predispose the patient to infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the bite of the Ixodes tick. Lyme arthritis would cause the man to develop asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis, but it would not present with conjunctivitis or urethritis. In addition, the patient did not have a history of erythema migrans or cardiac or neurological involvement, which are also characteristic of Lyme disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Norovirus is the most common cause of viral gastroenteritis in adults. The disease is usually self-limiting and resolves within 2–3 days. This man has clinical features suggestive of reactive arthritis, which can occur in susceptible individuals after gastroenteritis caused by bacteria such as Campylobacter, Salmonella, or Shigella, but not after viral infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient has a positive family history of SLE, which can present with arthritis, SLE does not present with either conjunctivitis or urethritis. Moreover, he does not have expected skin manifestations, such as a malar rash, or any other organ involvement to suggest SLE.

E) INCORRECT:

IV drug use would predispose the man to septic arthritis of his joints, most likely with Staphylococcus aureus. Septic arthritis would present as an acutely inflamed joint with fever, malaise, and chills. However, it would not present with conjunctivitis and urethritis.

F) INCORRECT:

Chondrocalcinosis is caused by deposition of calcium pyrophosphate crystals within the joints that can cause warm, tender joints similar to those seen in gouty arthritis. It can occur in hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypophosphatemia, renal osteodystrophy, and Wilson's disease, among others. This man has no clinical features suggestive of any of these conditions.
questions.hint: This young patient presents with the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, which is highly suggestive of reactive arthritis.

questions.text: A previously healthy 29-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of burning with urination for several days. He has also had pain in the right ankle for 3 days and pain and swelling in the left knee for 1 day. Two weeks ago, he had several days of fever and bloody diarrhea, for which he was treated with antibiotics. Examination shows a small left knee effusion and bilateral conjunctival injection. Which of the following is the most likely additional finding in this patient?

choices.text: Decreased mobility of the chest wall
Circular erythematous rash with central clearing
Pain on passive extension of the fingers
Palpable mass in the right lower quadrant
Tenderness at the insertion of the Achilles tendon
Nontender subcutaneous nodules over the olecranon

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ankylosing spondylitis causes decreased mobility of the chest wall and spine. Patients can present with arthritis, eye inflammation (typically uveitis), and a history of bloody diarrhea (from associated ulcerative colitis), as seen here. However, the characteristic manifestation of ankylosing spondylitis is neck and back pain causing stiffness that improves with activity, which is not seen in this patient. Additionally, this condition does not cause urethritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Erythema migrans, a circular, erythematous rash with central clearing, is pathognomonic for early, localized Lyme disease. The second stage of Lyme disease also causes migratory arthralgia and conjunctivitis. However, the lack of a tick bite or environmental exposures in this patient's history makes this diagnosis unlikely. Lyme disease is also inconsistent with this patient's preceding diarrheal illness or current urethritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) causes tenosynovitis, which results in pain on passive extension of the fingers. DGI typically presents with migratory arthralgia and is commonly preceded by urethritis, as seen here. However, DGI does not cause conjunctivitis and is not associated with preceding diarrheal illness. Additionally, a vesicular or pustular rash on the trunk and extremities would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Crohn disease can cause terminal ileitis, which manifests as a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant. Although arthritis and eye inflammation (more commonly episcleritis and uveitis) are extraintestinal manifestations of Crohn disease, this patient lacks the typical finding of recurrent, nonbloody diarrhea. Additionally, Crohn disease does not cause urethritis.

E) CORRECT:

Enthesitis causes tenderness at the insertion of the Achilles tendon, another common manifestation of reactive arthritis. Other features of reactive arthritis include sacroiliitis, dactylitis, oral lesions, and keratoderma blennorrhagicum. This patient likely had an acute gastrointestinal infection due to Shigella, Yersinia, Salmonella, or Campylobacter. Patients with reactive arthritis following an enteric infection can develop aseptic urethritis, which is likely the case in this patient.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection, which causes urethritis, is another potential preceding infection that can lead to reactive arthritis. Reactive arthritis has a strong association with the HLA-B27 haplotype.

F) INCORRECT:

Nontender subcutaneous nodules over the olecranon are consistent with rheumatoid nodules found in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. RA can also cause joint pain and eye inflammation (typically scleritis). However, the asymmetry of this patient's arthritis and involvement of large joints instead of small joints make this diagnosis unlikely. Additionally, this diagnosis is inconsistent with the patient's preceding diarrheal illness or current urethritis.
questions.hint: This patient's urethritis (dysuria), asymmetric oligoarticular arthritis, and conjunctivitis comprise the classic triad of reactive arthritis, a condition commonly triggered by diarrheal illness.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman with no notable medical history presents to the emergency department with pain in her back, left knee, and right ankle. She reports that the back pain began 3 weeks ago, frequently wakes her from sleep, is associated with stiffness in the morning, and improves with activity. Her left knee and right ankle have become warm, swollen, and painful during the past week, impairing her ability to work. Naproxen at therapeutic levels provides only mild relief.
The patient also reports conjunctivitis and dysuria. She has multiple male sexual partners and uses condoms intermittently. She states that she does not experience fevers or rash.
Physical examination reveals moderate swelling in the left knee, warmth and redness of the right ankle, and tenderness at the right upper buttock. Arthrocentesis of the knee effusion reveals cloudy synovial fluid containing 15,400 leukocytes per high-power field, with 85% neutrophils. Cultures of synovial fluid are negative.
Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis but negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months. In the up to 20% of patients with reactive arthritis who have arthritis that persists beyond several months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate, can be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is appropriate for treating gonococcal infection but not chlamydia.

D) CORRECT:

Reactive arthritis (formerly known as Reiter syndrome) is a spondyloarthritis, which classically manifests as arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis. Uveitis, fever, and other constitutional symptoms are also common features, as are acute pustular skin lesions known as keratoderma blennorrhagica. However, in more than 50% of affected patients, extra-articular manifestations are absent. Joint involvement, typically oligoarticular and asymmetric, often affects the lower extremities and may involve the spine (most frequently the sacroiliac joints).

Causative pathogens include Chlamydia trachomatis and enteric bacteria, such as Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, and Clostridioides difficile. Treatment involves eradicating the pathogen if there is evidence of ongoing infection, but in many cases, the precipitating infection has resolved before arthritis develops. In this case, the patient has active chlamydial infection, and gonorrheal infection has been ruled out.

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydia in a nonpregnant patient. Azithromycin is preferred during pregnancy and is a reasonable alternative in a nonpregnant patient when gonococcal infection has been ruled out, but it has inferior efficacy compared with doxycycline.

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months.

In the up to 20% of patients with reactive arthritis who have arthritis that persists beyond several months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate, can be considered.

Prolonged antibiotic treatment (with rifampin plus azithromycin or doxycycline) may benefit patients who have refractory, Chlamydia-induced reactive arthritis, particularly if there is evidence for persistence of bacteria in an attenuated form. However, polymerase chain-reaction testing of synovial tissue for such persistent infection is generally not available.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with reactive arthritis caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis but negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is doxycycline and a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a reasonable alternative in a nonpregnant patient when gonococcal infection has been ruled out, but it has inferior efficacy compared with doxycycline.

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months. In the up to 20% of patients with reactive arthritis who have arthritis that persists beyond several months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate, can be considered.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of unilateral knee pain and swelling. Each morning he has stiffness that persists for at least an hour, and his daytime activity is limited by pain. He has also noted a painful, bumpy rash on his shins, recurrent mouth ulcers, intermittent abdominal pain, frequent bowel movements, and fatigue. He has lost approximately 4.5 kg during the past 3 months.
His vital signs are unremarkable other than a heart rate of 105 beats per minute. He is thin, with a BMI of 17.5. He has three oral ulcers. His abdomen is diffusely tender with no masses or hepatosplenomegaly.
He has tenderness and decreased range of motion in his right knee, with a measurable effusion. The hips, left knee, and ankles are all normal. He has 5 to 10 tender, red nodules on both of his shins.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Hemoglobin (g/dL)
8.9
13.5–17.5


Mean corpuscular volume (μm3)
69
80–100


Albumin (g/dL)
2.6
3.5–5.5


Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (mm per hour)
55
0–17


C-reactive protein (mg/liter)
3.5
0.08–3.10


Uric acid (mg/dL)
3.1
2.5–8.0


Serologic testing for Lyme disease, rheumatoid factor, and anti-citrullinated peptic antibodies is negative.
Aspiration of the right knee joint yields 55 mL of nonbloody but cloudy yellow fluid with a nucleated cell count of 13,200 per mm3 (25% polymorphonucleated cells). Analysis by compensated polarized light microscopy is negative for the presence of any crystals. Gram stain and culture are negative for any microorganisms.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Serologic analysis rules out Lyme arthritis (which invariably is positive in the setting of the chronic monoarthritis phase).

B) INCORRECT:

Although arthritis is the most common manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis, the involvement of only a single joint in this patient, the negative serologies, and the presence of gastrointestinal symptoms and erythema nodosum all favor the IBD arthropathy diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The arthritis with SLE is usually a small-joint inflammatory polyarthritis.

D) CORRECT:

Joint pain is a common extraintestinal manifestation of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), affecting approximately 20% to 30% of adults with IBD. Joint inflammation in IBD can involve the sacroiliac joint and axial skeleton (similar to ankylosing spondylitis), or it can be a peripheral arthritis, dactylitis, or tenosynovitis. IBD arthropathy should be considered a diagnosis of exclusion, even in a patient with known IBD; alternative diagnoses could include septic arthritis, Lyme arthritis, microcrystalline arthritis, or even other forms of autoimmune arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis.

Other common extraintestinal manifestations of IBD are oral ulcers, anemia, and erythema nodosum. Gastrointestinal symptoms usually precede joint disease by months to years, but they can also occur simultaneously, or the joint symptoms can precede the gastrointestinal symptoms.

A diagnosis of IBD should be suspected in any patient who has arthritis accompanied by lower abdominal pain, hematochezia, unexplained weight loss, anemia, or fever.

The arthritis that accompanies IBD typically improves after effective treatment of the bowel disease. However, the axial involvement in IBD is much more likely to persist and progress independent of the activity of the bowel disease.

Lyme arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and gouty arthritis can all initially manifest with joint pain. However, the constellation of symptoms described in this patient is not fully consistent with any of these clinical entities.

In this case, septic arthritis has been ruled out by microbiologic analysis of joint fluid. Gonococcal arthritis remains an unlikely possibility and could be ruled out by testing for gonococcus. Sarcoid arthritis could manifest as a chronic inflammatory arthritis, erythema nodosum, and wasting. If this patient did not demonstrate other features of IBD, then one would need to consider biopsy of an affected organ or tissue to assess for the presence of noncaseating granulomas of sarcoid.

Key learning point: The most likely underlying diagnosis in a patient with inflammatory arthritis, diarrhea, oral ulcers, anemia, and erythema nodosum is inflammatory bowel disease.

E) INCORRECT:

The low-normal serum uric acid level and the lack of crystals on joint fluid analysis make gouty arthritis very unlikely.

questions.text:
A previously healthy 7-year-old girl presents with a 5-day history of pain and swelling in her right knee and difficulty ambulating. She has not had any fever during this time. Two weeks ago, she was hospitalized for 5 days of fever and had a negative workup, including negative blood cultures.
Today, she appears well and has normal vital signs. Her right knee is swollen with a joint effusion. Her left wrist is swollen and mildly tender, but there is no overlying erythema. Her right Achilles tendon is very swollen and tender without overlying warmth and erythema.
What is the most appropriate next step in this patient's care?

choices.text: Initiate treatment with intravenous vancomycin and cefepime
Refer the patient to a physical therapist
Perform arthrocentesis of the right knee
Inject triamcinolone into the right knee

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the joint is essential for suspected septic arthritis, as is empiric intravenous antibiotics while awaiting culture results. However, in an afebrile patient with more than one inflamed joint and with tendon/enthesis involvement, the possibility of an infected joint is remote.

B) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy would be indicated after injury or for other rehabilitation but is not the first step in a patient with acute arthritis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's current clinical presentation and history of recent infection suggests a diagnosis of postinfectious arthritis, also known as reactive arthritis.

Postinfectious arthritis encompasses diverse presentations of inflammatory disease in the joints and often other organ systems, particularly the eyes (uveitis or conjunctivitis) and skin, following an infection. The peripheral arthritis is typically oligoarticular and asymmetric; it can also involve entheses (sites of attachment between tendons and bone) and the axial skeleton (e.g., spinal entheses and sacroiliac joints) and is classified among the spondyloarthropathies.

Postinfectious arthritis is usually triggered by enteric or genital bacterial infections, particularly Chlamydia, Yersinia, Salmonella, Shigella, or Campylobacter. The association with one of these infections and/or the presence of enthesopathy, axial involvement, or extraarticular inflammation helps to distinguish postinfectious arthritis from other problems, such as poststreptococcal arthritis and postviral arthritis. Additional investigations are unnecessary if there is evidence of a preceding infection and the presentation is not suggestive of another form of inflammatory arthritis or septic arthritis, including Lyme arthritis.

In most cases, the disease is self-limited, and family reassurance is appropriate and important. However, some patients experience recurrent episodes of arthritis, and a small percentage develop chronic enthesitis-related arthritis, especially if they are HLA-B27-positive.

Antibiotic treatment has not been shown to benefit patients with postinfectious arthritis; in most cases, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) treatment suffices. If NSAIDs are not sufficient, a trial of systemic or localized glucocorticoids may be warranted.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for postinfectious arthritis is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication.

D) INCORRECT:

Arthrocentesis of the joint is essential for suspected septic arthritis, as is empiric intravenous antibiotics while awaiting culture results. However, in an afebrile patient with more than one inflamed joint and with tendon/enthesis involvement, the possibility of an infected joint is remote.

E) INCORRECT:

Antibiotic treatment has not been shown to benefit patients with postinfectious arthritis; in most cases, nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) treatment suffices. If NSAIDs are not sufficient, a trial of systemic or localized glucocorticoids may be warranted.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with pain in her back, left knee, and right ankle. She reports that the back pain began 3 weeks ago. Her left knee and right ankle have become warm, swollen, and painful during the past week. The patient also reports conjunctivitis and dysuria. She has multiple male sexual partners and uses condoms intermittently. Physical examination reveals moderate swelling in the left knee, warmth and redness of the right ankle, and tenderness at the right upper buttock. Urine polymerase-chain-reaction testing is positive for Chlamydia trachomatis but negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae. A pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?

A) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months. In the up to 20% of patients with reactive arthritis who have arthritis that persists beyond several months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate, can be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is appropriate for treating gonococcal infection but not chlamydia.

In this case, the patient has active chlamydial infection, and gonorrheal infection has been ruled out.

Doxycycline is the preferred treatment for chlamydia in a nonpregnant patient. Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment for a patient with reactive arthritis caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis but negative for Neisseria gonorrhoeae is doxycycline and a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory medication.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is a reasonable alternative in a nonpregnant patient when gonococcal infection has been ruled out, but it has inferior efficacy compared with doxycycline.

Nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug (NSAID) therapy is the first choice for control of arthritis, and it is not uncommon for more than one NSAID to be tried in an attempt to find an effective agent. Systemic or intra-articular glucocorticoids are indicated if NSAIDs are ineffective. The average disease duration for reactive arthritis is 3 to 6 months. In the up to 20% of patients with reactive arthritis who have arthritis that persists beyond several months, disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs, such as methotrexate, can be considered.
questions.hint: This patient's urethritis (dysuria), asymmetric oligoarticular arthritis, and conjunctivitis comprise the classic triad of reactive arthritis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with a two-week history of painful swelling in his right knee and left ankle. Three weeks ago, he had an episode of watery diarrhea that resolved spontaneously. Over the past week, he has noticed pain at the Achilles tendon insertion behind his heel. He denies any rashes, eye redness, or urethral discharge. Examination reveals moderate effusion of the right knee and tenderness at the left Achilles insertion (see lab results).

Temperature
37.5°C



Test
Result
Normal Values



Joint fluid




 WBC
8000/μL
< 200/μL


Rheumatoid factor
Negative
<58 kIU/L


Anti-CCP antibody
Negative
Negative



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory condition often triggered by a preceding infection, typically gastrointestinal or genitourinary. The patient's history of watery diarrhea, asymmetric oligoarthritis involving the knee and ankle, and enthesitis at the Achilles tendon insertion strongly support this diagnosis. Joint fluid analysis reveals an inflammatory profile with elevated white blood cell counts, while remaining sterile. The absence of rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies differentiates reactive arthritis from other inflammatory arthritides, such as rheumatoid arthritis.

Key learning point: Reactive arthritis is characterized by asymmetric oligoarthritis, enthesitis, and occurs after certain infections, with negative cultures supporting the diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Gout typically presents with acute inflammatory arthritis, often affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint (podagra). The patient's age, joint involvement, and history of diarrhea suggest an inflammatory process triggered by infection, not characteristic of gout. Joint aspiration in gout reveals monosodium urate crystals, which is not mentioned here.

C) INCORRECT:

Psoriatic arthritis is associated with skin lesions like psoriatic plaques and nail changes, which are absent in this patient. The history of diarrhea preceding arthritis suggests a reactive process. Although enthesitis can occur in psoriatic arthritis, the lack of dermatologic findings and the clinical context make this diagnosis unlikely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents as symmetric polyarthritis affecting small joints, with morning stiffness. The patient's asymmetric joint involvement and Achilles tendon enthesitis are atypical. The history of diarrhea suggests a post-infectious etiology, not associated with rheumatoid arthritis. Negative rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies further argue against this diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 17-year-old boy who presents with a 12-day history of increasing pain and swelling in his right knee. Over the past 3 weeks, he has also had episodes of dysuria. He previously had a tender, swollen left ankle joint that resolved without treatment one week ago. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His temperature is 38°C. On examination, there is bilateral conjunctival inflammation. The right knee is tender, erythematous, and swollen, and there is tenderness at the left Achilles tendon insertion. Arthrocentesis of the right knee reveals synovial fluid with a leukocyte count of 26 × 109/L (70% neutrophils); Gram stain shows no organisms. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Disseminated gonococcal infection can manifest in two ways: either with a triad of polyarthritis, tenosynovitis, and dermatitis, or as purulent arthritis (without affection of skin and tendons). This patient's presentation is not consistent with either form. He does have arthritis (but only in a single joint) and tenosynovitis, but lacks cutaneous manifestations. His arthrocentesis did show a high neutrophil count, but the leukocyte count is too low and there were no gonococci on the Gram stain (note that the Gram stain is only positive in < 25% of cases). Even though this does not rule out gonococcal infection, disseminated gonococcal infection usually does not cause urethritis and conjunctivitis (only 25% of patients with gonococcal infection present with genitourinary manifestations).

B) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis would cause the same local symptoms seen in this patient. Furthermore, the expected arthrocentesis findings in Lyme arthritis are consistent with this case: specifically, > 50% neutrophils, increased WBCs (> 25 × 109/L), and no organisms on Gram stain. Nevertheless, the patient is missing all the typical findings of Lyme disease, including history of a tick bite, erythema chronicum migrans, and flu-like symptoms. Even if stage I went unnoticed and the patient were now in stage II of Lyme disease (with migratory arthralgia), it would not explain his tendinopathy, conjunctivitis, or pain on urination.

C) CORRECT:

Asymmetric oligoarthritis with a migratory character (left ankle → right knee), tendinopathy, and conjunctivitis are typical manifestations of reactive arthritis. This patient's pain on urination is most likely a symptom of a preceding urinary tract infection, as reactive arthritis is a postinfectious autoimmune disorder. The disorder most commonly affects sexually active young men, as they have a higher risk of acquiring STDs, e.g., genitourinary infections with Chlamydia. The arthrocentesis findings are also consistent with this diagnosis, as they tend to show increased WBCs and neutrophils but no organisms. Reactive arthritis can also occur in response to infection with other organisms such as Shigella or Campylobacter. Management includes NSAIDs, physiotherapy, and cryotherapy, and, if applicable, treatment of ongoing infection.

See “Differential diagnoses of infection-associated arthritis” table.

Key learning point: Reactive arthritis is a postinfectious autoimmune condition characterized by asymmetric oligoarthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis, often following genitourinary or gastrointestinal infections.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient has no history of a chancre or regional lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis). Moreover, he does not have a polymorphic rash, constitutional symptoms (e.g., generalized lymphadenopathy, fever), or condylomata lata (secondary syphilis).

E) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis would also present with limited range of motion and the typical combination of erythema, warmth, and swelling. In a patient with no risk factors (e.g., IV drug use), however, it is not very likely. This patient also presents with extraarticular symptoms that make a generalized disease more likely. Furthermore, the leukocyte count (26 × 109/L) is far lower than expected (> 50 × 109/L), and the absence of organisms on Gram stain rules out the most common bacterial causes of septic arthritis.
questions.hint: This condition classically manifests with the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of right knee swelling and pain. He reports loose stools 3 weeks ago that resolved without treatment. He now has bilateral eye irritation and dysuria without urethral discharge. His last sexual contact was 4 months ago. Vital signs are normal and he is afebrile. Joint aspiration yields inflammatory fluid with 25,000 WBC/mm³, predominantly neutrophils. Gram stain is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis remains a concern with inflammatory synovial fluid, but several factors make this diagnosis less likely. While the synovial fluid shows inflammatory changes with 25,000 WBC/mm³ and neutrophil predominance, this count falls below the typical threshold for septic arthritis (> 50,000/mm³). Although a negative gram stain is not reliable to rule out septic arthritis (with a sensitivity of only 29–65% in native joints), the afebrile presentation and extraarticular symptoms, including bilateral conjunctivitis and urethritis, favor a postinfectious etiology.

B) INCORRECT:

While disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) can present with a negative synovial Gram stain and extraarticular manifestations, including conjunctivitis and urethritis, several factors make this diagnosis less likely. DGI onset is variable and can be within days and up to 2 months after an untreated gonococcal urethritis. This patient's last sexual contact was 4 months ago, well outside this window. Also, the majority of patients with DGI (~ 70 %) do not have active mucosal symptoms simultaneously with gonococcal arthritis. This patient's temporal relationship between the resolved gastrointestinal illness 3 weeks ago, plus the triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis, is more consistent with a postinfectious autoimmune process.

C) INCORRECT:

Gout would show uric acid crystals on synovial fluid analysis under polarized microscopy. The patient's age, lack of crystal arthropathy risk factors, and extraarticular symptoms make gout unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Reactive arthritis classically presents with the triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis following a gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. The 1-4 week latency period after diarrheal illness and combination of joint and extraarticular symptoms suggest a postinfectious autoimmune etiology. Synovial fluid findings for reactive arthritis include a WBC count in the 5,000–50,000/mm³ range, and negative Gram stain and culture. The differential diagnoses of infection-associated arthritis can overlap. Careful history taking is vital to identify the correct diagnosis in acute settings.

E) INCORRECT:

Lyme arthritis typically presents as chronic monoarthritis in endemic areas with outdoor exposure history. The acute presentation following gastrointestinal infection with conjunctivitis and urethritis is not characteristic of Lyme disease.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man presents with a 4-day history of right knee swelling and left ankle pain. He reports mild conjunctival irritation and dysuria but denies fever. Three weeks ago, he had self-limiting diarrhea lasting 5 days. Physical examination shows asymmetrical joint swelling affecting the knee and ankle with decreased range of motion. Laboratory studies show ESR 45 mm/hr, CRP 12 mg/L, and synovial fluid analysis shows watery yellow fluid with WBC 15,000/mm³ (90% neutrophils) and a negative Gram stain on microscopy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial treatment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Joint aspiration and drainage would be the treatment for septic arthritis with purulent material requiring evacuation. This patient's synovial fluid is watery and shows a WBC count in the inflammatory range (> 2,000 WBC/mm³) and less than the typical septic range (> 50,000 WBC/mm³). The negative Gram stain also makes sterile inflammation a stronger possibility, even though it does not rule out septic arthritis on its own. While septic arthritis can occasionally have lower WBC counts and a negative Gram stain, the clinical context of post-infectious oligoarthritis with extraarticular features is more consistent with an alternative inflamamtory diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Empiric intravenous antibiotics would be the treatment for septic arthritis. While the synovial fluid WBC count of 15,000/mm³ with neutrophil predominance could raise concern for this diagnosis, this count falls in the inflammatory range (> 2,000 WBC/mm³) rather than the typical septic range (i.e., > 50,000/mm³). Septic arthritis can occasionally present with lower WBC counts and a negative Gram stain, as its sensitivity is low for this condition. The clinical context, however, more strongly favors an inflammatory postinfectious arthritis: the oligoarticular pattern, extraarticular symptoms (conjunctivitis, urethritis), and temporal relationship to gastroenteritis. The absence of fever and the specific constellation of symptoms also make septic arthritis less likely despite the inflammatory synovial fluid.

C) INCORRECT:

Colchicine would be the treatment for acute gout. The synovial fluid shows inflammatory arthritis with neutrophil predominance but lacks the monosodium urate crystals that would be seen in gout. Additionally, gout typically presents as severe monoarthritis often affecting the first metatarsophalangeal joint, not oligoarthritis with extraarticular symptoms following gastroenteritis.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient has reactive arthritis based on the oligoarthritis with asymmetrical distribution, extraarticular symptoms (conjunctivitis, urethritis), and latency period following gastrointestinal infection. The synovial fluid shows elevated WBC count (5,000-50,000/mm³ range) with neutrophil predominance and negative Gram stain, which is characteristic of reactive arthritis. Intraarticular corticosteroids would be second-line treatment for reactive arthritis or treatment for inflammatory arthritis when first-line treatment is contraindicated or ineffective.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has reactive arthritis based on the oligoarthritis with asymmetrical distribution, extraarticular symptoms (conjunctivitis, urethritis), and latency period following gastrointestinal infection. The synovial fluid shows elevated WBC count (5,000-50,000/mm³ range) with neutrophil predominance and negative Gram stain, which is characteristic of reactive arthritis. High-dose NSAIDs are the first-line treatment for this self-limiting condition.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man returns to the emergency department with worsening joint pain and swelling affecting his right knee and left ankle. Two weeks ago, he presented with a 4-day history of asymmetrical joint pain following a diarrheal illness and was started on high-dose ibuprofen after arthrocentesis. Synovial fluid analysis from that visit showed: WBC count 25,000/mm³ (88% neutrophils), negative Gram stain, and cultures remaining negative at 72 hours. Despite full adherence to maximum-dose ibuprofen, his symptoms have progressively worsened. Physical examination shows increased swelling and warmth of the affected joints with further limitation of range of motion. Vital signs are BP, 124/82; P, 88; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F). ESR is 72 mm/hr and CRP is 52 mg/L. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intraarticular corticosteroid injection and orthopedic surgery referral
Repeat arthrocentesis and infectious disease referral
Opioid analgesics and pain management referral

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient has reactive arthritis with inadequate response to NSAIDs after 2 weeks and worsening symptoms. Systemic glucocorticoids like prednisone are indicated for patients with inadequate response or contraindications to NSAIDs. Rheumatology referral is appropriate for patients with persistent or severe inflammation requiring specialist evaluation for potential DMARD therapy.

B) INCORRECT:

Intraarticular corticosteroids are appropriate for isolated active joints, but this patient has polyarthritis with systemic inflammation, evidenced by elevated ESR and CRP. Additionally, intraarticular injections carry a risk of introducing infection and are typically performed by specialists rather than in the emergency department for reactive arthritis management. Orthopedic surgery referral is not indicated for reactive arthritis, which is a medical inflammatory condition requiring anti-inflammatory treatment rather than surgical intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Repeat arthrocentesis is not indicated when previous synovial fluid analysis excluded septic arthritis with negative cultures at 72 hours. The patient's afebrile status and clinical presentation consistent with reactive arthritis do not warrant infectious disease consultation at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Opioid analgesics do not address the underlying inflammatory process in reactive arthritis and carry risks of dependence. Pain management referral is not appropriate for inflammatory arthritis, which requires anti-inflammatory treatment rather than symptomatic pain control alone.

E) INCORRECT:

Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) that requires rheumatology supervision and is not typically initiated by internal medicine in the acute setting. DMARDs are considered after adequate trials of NSAIDs and corticosteroids, not as immediate second-line therapy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with a 2-week history of progressive pain and swelling in his right knee and left ankle. He also reports bilateral eye redness and irritation. He denies any recent trauma. The patient mentions that 4 weeks prior, he was treated with a single dose of azithromycin for urethral discharge after a new sexual encounter. On examination, there is conjunctival injection. The right knee and left ankle are warm, swollen, and tender to palpation. There are several shallow, painless ulcers on the glans penis. Arthrocentesis of the right knee shows a WBC count of 25,000/mm³ with a predominance of neutrophils, and the Gram stain is negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis, but it typically manifests as a chronic, symmetric polyarthritis affecting the small joints of the hands and feet. This patient's presentation is acute, asymmetric, and involves large, lower-extremity joints. The preceding urethritis, conjunctivitis, and penile ulcers are not features of rheumatoid arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Septic arthritis manifests with an acute, hot, swollen joint. However, it is typically a monoarthritis, and the synovial fluid WBC count is often much higher (usually > 50,000/mm³). Most importantly, the Gram stain and subsequent culture of the synovial fluid would be positive for a causative organism, which is not the case here. The extra-articular findings are also not typical for septic arthritis.

C) INCORRECT:

Gout can cause an acute, inflammatory oligoarthritis. However, it is uncommon in a 24-year-old man without specific risk factors. The diagnosis of gout relies on identifying negatively birefringent, needle-shaped crystals in the synovial fluid, which is not described. Furthermore, the extra-articular manifestations of conjunctivitis, urethritis, and penile ulcers are not associated with gout.

D) INCORRECT:

Gonococcal arthritis is a consideration in a young, sexually active patient with acute arthritis. However, it typically manifests as either a purulent monoarthritis or the triad of tenosynovitis, dermatitis (pustular lesions), and migratory polyarthralgias. Additionally, the Gram stain is often positive for Gram-negative diplococci. The presence of conjunctivitis and circinate balanitis is not characteristic of this condition.

E) CORRECT:

The triad of conjunctivitis, urethritis (preceding), and asymmetric oligoarthritis suggests reactive arthritis. This condition is an autoimmune response triggered by a preceding infection, typically genitourinary (e.g., Chlamydia trachomatis) or gastrointestinal. The onset of arthritis 1–4 weeks after the initial infection is characteristic. The synovial fluid analysis shows an inflammatory but sterile aspirate (negative Gram stain), which is a key feature. The presence of circinate balanitis (painless penile ulcers) further supports this diagnosis. There is a strong association with the HLA-B27 antigen, which is present in the majority of patients.
questions.hint: Consider the connection between this patient's recent sexually transmitted infection and the subsequent development of the classic triad of arthritis, conjunctivitis, and urethritis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician for frequent and painful urination. He has also had progressive painful swelling of his right knee over the past week. He is sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His mother has an autoimmune disease that involves a malar rash. Examination shows conjunctivitis bilaterally. The right knee is warm, erythematous, and tender to touch; range of motion is limited. Laboratory studies show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 62 mm/h. Urinalysis shows WBCs. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A hiking trip might predispose the patient to infection with Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted through the bite of the ixodid tick. Lyme arthritis would cause the patient to develop asymmetrical migratory polyarthritis, but it would not present with conjunctivitis or urethritis. In addition, the patient did not have a history of erythema migrans or cardiac or neurological involvement, which are also characteristic of Lyme disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Norovirus is the most common cause of viral gastroenteritis in adults. The disease is usually self-limiting and resolves within 2–3 days. This patient has clinical features suggestive of reactive arthritis, which can occur in susceptible individuals after gastroenteritis caused by bacteria such as Campylobacter, Salmonella, or Shigella, but not after viral infections.

C) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are highly specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Although this patient has a positive family history that likely involves SLE (i.e., autoimmune disease involving a malar rash), which can present with arthritis, SLE does not present with either conjunctivitis or urethritis. Moreover, he does not have expected skin manifestations, such as a malar rash or any other organ involvement to suggest SLE.

D) INCORRECT:

IV drug use would predispose the man to septic arthritis of his joints, most likely with Staphylococcus aureus. Septic arthritis would present as an acutely inflamed joint with fever, malaise, and chills. However, it would not present with conjunctivitis and urethritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Chondrocalcinosis is caused by CPPD crystal deposition within the joints that can cause warm, tender joints similar to those seen in gouty arthritis. It can occur in hyperparathyroidism, hypothyroidism, hemochromatosis, hypophosphatemia, renal osteodystrophy, and Wilson disease, among others. This man has no clinical features suggestive of any of these diseases.

F) CORRECT:

Reactive arthritis occurs in genetically susceptible individuals in response to an infection with Chlamydia, Shigella, or Campylobacter, among other organisms. An HLA-B27 genotype is present in over two-thirds of patients with reactive arthritis. Those with reactive arthritis and a positive HLA-B27 genotype should be screened for other diseases associated with the same genotype, such as ankylosing spondylitis and acute anterior uveitis. Given this patient's sexual history, he should also be screened for HIV, which is associated with a higher risk of reactive arthritis.
questions.hint: This young patient has a triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis, which is highly suggestive of reactive arthritis.
